questions.text: Samples for virological examination are preserved in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Gycerol • For enzyme studies, blood is preserved in liquid nitrogen in Thermos flask. • Toluene is the best preservative for urine. The other preservatives for urine are hydrochloric acid, thymol and Sodium fluoride (NaF is used in case of poisoning by Alcohol, CO, Cocaine and Cyanide). • For virological examination, a piece of appropriate tissue is collected under sterile conditions and the sample is freezed or preserved in 80% glycerol in buffered saline.

questions.text: Species identification is done by
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Precipitin test • Precipitin test is species specific test which is used to identify the species of any body fluid or tissue. • Neutron activation analysis is used to identify the metals. • Spectroscopic examination is a confirmatory test for blood. • Benzidine test is a presumptive test for blood.

questions.text: If father's blood group is A and mother's blood group is B, the child's blood group will be
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) A, AB, B, or O The blood group of the child depends on the ABO inheritance, which follows Mendelian genetics. The ABO blood group system has three alleles: IA, IB, and i. IA and IB are co-dominant, meaning both can be expressed when present together (resulting in blood group AB). i is recessive, meaning it is only expressed if inherited from both parents (resulting in blood group O). If the father's blood group is A (genotype IAIA or IAi) and the mother's blood group is B (genotype IBIB or IBi), the possible combinations of alleles in the child are: IAIB: Blood group AB IAi: Blood group A IBi: Blood group B ii: Blood group O Thus, the child could have blood group A, B, AB, or O, depending on the alleles inherited from each parent. Incorrect Options: A. A only: This is incorrect because the child could inherit IA from the father and IB from the mother, resulting in blood group AB. Similarly, the child could inherit IB from the mother and i from the father, resulting in blood group B. Blood group O is also possible if the child inherits i from both parents. B. B only: This is incorrect for the same reason. Blood group B is possible, but the child could also have A, AB, or O depending on the genetic combinations inherited. C. AB only: This is incorrect because AB is only one of the possibilities when IA is inherited from the father and IB from the mother. Other combinations (e.g., IAi, IBi, or ii) would result in blood groups A, B, or O.

questions.text: Prinsloo-Gorden artefact in cases of neck compression is seen
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Beneath the esophagus • Apparent "bruising" of the neck musculature does not always indicate compression of or trauma to the neck. • In any autopsy, substantial haemorrhage may be seen over the posterior surface of the oesophagus and the anterior longitudinal ligament of the cervical spine. • This is a common post mortem artefact described fully by Prinsloo and Gordon, sometimes known by their name. • This can be reduced to certain extent by bloodless field of dissection of the neck.

questions.text: Minimum quantity of blood required to be preserved for chemical analysis is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 10 ml For chemical analysis, particularly in forensic and toxicological investigations, 10 ml of blood is typically the minimum required quantity to ensure that sufficient sample is available for all necessary tests. This amount allows for multiple analyses, including detection of toxins, alcohol, drugs, or other substances. The preserved blood sample can also be subjected to reanalysis if needed, which makes 10 ml the preferred minimum volume. Incorrect Options: B. 2 ml: While 2 ml might be adequate for basic tests or specific analyses (e.g., a single drug or alcohol level), it is insufficient for comprehensive chemical analysis, which often requires larger quantities for multiple tests or repeat testing. C. 100 ml: 100 ml is far more than what is required for chemical analysis. Collecting such a large volume is unnecessary and impractical, especially in cases involving deceased individuals or those with limited blood availability. D. 50 ml: Similar to 100 ml, 50 ml is excessive and unnecessary for routine chemical analysis. While a larger quantity might be collected for research purposes or advanced testing, it is not a standard requirement.

questions.text: When an autopsy surgeon wants to send the maggots for examination, it should be preserved in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Acetic alcohol • Supersaturated sodium chloride or rectified spirit is used as a preservative for body viscera. • Acetic alcohol is used as preservative for maggots. Maggots are killed by dropping into boiling absolute alcohol (so that it dies in extended position) and preserved in Acetic alcohol. • Dimethyl sulphoxide (DMSO) is used as a preservative for muscle for DNA.

choices.text: The examination should be meticulous and complete
Routinely record all positive findings and important negative ones
He must keep the police informed about the findings
He must preserve viscera and send for toxicology examination in case of poisoning

questions.text: Certain obligations on the part of doctor who under takes post-mortem examination are following except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) He must keep the police informed about the findings • A medicolegal autopsy is to be carried out at the behest of the appropriate legal authority. The request/order may move from the police officer (usually the station house officer or sub-inspector of police) or from magistrate or from Coroner under whose jurisdiction the incidence/ event leading to death occurred. • A doctor should record all positive findings and important negative ones. • No autopsy is complete unless all three major body cavities are opened, i.e. cranial, thoracic and abdominal cavities. • A doctor must preserve viscera and send for toxicology examination in case of poisoning/suspected poisoning/where there are no other findings/when requested by the investigating officer. No unauthorised person should be permitted to enter the mortuary. No police official should be present while the autopsy is being conducted and no need to keep the police informed about the findings.

questions.text: The best preservative for blood for culture is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Sodium polyanethole sulfonate • EDTA or Heparin is used as preservative for blood for DNA. • Sodium / Potassium fluoride, 10 mg/ml (prevents glycolysis, inhibits enzymatic activity and bacterial growth) + K oxalate is used as preservative for blood. • Sodium polyanethole sulfonate (SPS) is an anticoagulant which is used for blood for culture.

questions.text: Pyrogallol test helps to differentiate
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Air embolism from putrefactive gas • Alkaline pyrogallol test helps to differentiate air embolism from putrefactive gases. • 4 ml of alkaline pyrogallol is taken in a 10ml syringe and air is aspirated from right side of the heart. • The needle is removed and replaced by a stopper. • If air (Oxygen) is present, the mixture turns brown on shaking. • In a second syringe, some air is introduced by the atmosphere and the test is repeated as a control.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a feature of post-mortem clot?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Adherence to the wall • Differentiation between Ante-mortem and Post-mortem clots: • The ante mortem clots are firm, rubbery and attached to the vessel wall by lines of Zahn. • Post mortem clots are soft, friable, having appearance of red currant jelly (red cells)/ yellow chicken fat (serum) and not attached to the vessel wall by lines of Zahn. • Post-mortem fibrinous clots in the heart are known as Cardiac Polyps.

questions.text: The amount of soil to be collected at the time of exhumation is about
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) 500 grams • During exhumation, in case of suspected poisoning, 6 soil samples of 500 g each should be taken from each side of the body or coffin, i.e., above the body, below the body, both sides of the body, head end of the body and foot end of the body. • In addition, at least two samples must be taken from some distance (sample soil) - say around 25 to 30 yards from the grave. • In suspected mineral poisoning, hair, nails, and long bone e.g., femur should be preserved for chemical analysis.

questions.text: Fracture at C6 - C7 vertebrae is called
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Undertaker’s fracture • Fracture of C2-C3 is known as Hangman’s fracture. • Undertaker’s fracture is caused due to the head falling backwards forcibly after death, which tears open one of the intervertebral disc usually around C-6 and C-7. • Fracure of C1 is known as Jefferson’s fracture.

questions.text: Acid phosphatase activity of human semen in Bodansky units per ml is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 340–360 Bodansky units/ml The acid phosphatase (ACP) activity in human semen is an important marker used in forensic investigations to confirm the presence of semen in biological samples. The typical range of acid phosphatase activity in human semen is 340–360 Bodansky units per ml, as it is highly concentrated in seminal fluid, originating from the prostate gland. This range is widely recognized and utilized in forensic toxicology and biochemistry for semen identification. Incorrect Options: A. 240–260 Bodansky units/ml: This range is lower than the typical activity level of acid phosphatase in human semen. Such levels are not consistent with the physiological concentration in semen. B. 300–320 Bodansky units/ml: While closer to the correct range, this value is still lower than the commonly accepted range of 340–360 Bodansky units/ml found in semen. D. 380–400 Bodansky units/ml: This range is slightly higher than the usual levels of acid phosphatase activity in semen, making it less accurate.

questions.text: One of the following is generally not a constituent of embalming fluid
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Ethanol Ethanol is generally not a constituent of embalming fluid. Embalming fluid is a chemical solution used to preserve human remains by delaying decomposition and disinfecting the body. It is typically composed of chemicals that have preservative, fixative, and germicidal properties, such as formalin, methanol, and phenol. Ethanol, although a preservative in certain contexts, is not commonly used in standard embalming fluids. Constituents of Embalming Fluid: Formalin (Formaldehyde): Formalin is a key component of embalming fluid. It serves as a preservative and fixative, preventing the decomposition of tissues by cross-linking proteins. Methanol: Methanol is added to embalming fluid to stabilize formaldehyde and prevent polymerization. It also acts as a disinfectant and preservative. Phenol: Phenol is included for its antiseptic and preservative properties. It aids in the disinfection process and prevents microbial growth. Why Ethanol is Incorrect: Ethanol, while it has disinfectant properties, is not typically used in embalming fluid because it is not as effective as the other compounds in preserving tissues or disinfecting remains. Additionally, ethanol is volatile and could evaporate easily, making it unsuitable for long-term preservation. Incorrect Options: B. Methanol: Methanol is an essential component of embalming fluid and is used to stabilize formaldehyde, making this option incorrect. C. Formalin: Formalin is the main preservative in embalming fluid, making this option incorrect. D. Phenol: Phenol is included for its antiseptic and disinfectant properties, making this option incorrect.

questions.text: Phadebas test is used to detect
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Saliva • Phadebas test and/or Starch-Iodine Test/Alpha-Amylase (or α-Amylase) test are used to detect Saliva and can be confirmed by the Presence of buccal squamous cell. • Presence of Colostrum: By the detection of Trypsin inhibitor. • Presence of Milk: By the detection of Casein and Lactose. • Chemical tests to detect urine from the stains depend on the presence of Urea and creatinine.

questions.text: Which of the following is used for narcoanalysis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Scopolamine • Narcoanalysis is a procedure of investigation of mental content of a person done after application of a light general anaesthetic drugs. • This investigative technique is based on the principle that at a point very close to unconsciousness, the subject would be mentally incapable of resistance to questioning and incapable of inventing falsehood that he has used to conceal his guilt. • Drugs commonly used are 1. Thiopentone sodium (Na Pentothal) 2. Scopolamine hydrobromide 3. Sodium seconol 4. Sodium amytal 5. Benzodiazepines

questions.text: The term MERMER is related to
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Brain fingerprinting • Brain fingerprinting is invented by Lawrence Farwell. • It is a technique that uses electroencephalography (EEG) to determine whether specific information is stored in a subject's brain by measuring electrical brainwaves and recording a brain response known as a P300-MERMER (memory and encoding related multifaceted electroencephalographic response) in response to words, phrases, or pictures that are presented on a computer screen.

questions.text: ABO antigen are found in all except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) CSF ABO antigens are expressed on red blood cells and can also be found in certain body fluids in individuals who are secretors (those who have the FUT2 gene). These antigens are present in fluids such as saliva, sweat, and gastric juice but are not found in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). CSF lacks the necessary glycoproteins to express ABO antigens. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) does not contain ABO antigens because the secretor status (expression of ABO antigens in body fluids) does not extend to the CSF. CSF is produced by the choroid plexus and has a composition distinct from other body fluids. Incorrect Options: A. Saliva: ABO antigens are commonly found in saliva, provided the person is a secretor. Secretors express soluble forms of ABO antigens in their body fluids. B. Sweat: Sweat contains ABO antigens in secretors because these antigens are expressed on epithelial cells and secreted into body fluids. D. Gastric juice: ABO antigens are present in gastric juice in secretors, as the stomach lining expresses these antigens in its secretions.

questions.text: What is the investigation of choice for blood grouping in old blood stain on cloth
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Acid dilution test The acid dilution test is the investigation of choice for determining the ABO blood group from an old bloodstain on cloth. This test is effective for identifying blood group antigens in dried blood because the antigens on red blood cells are relatively stable even in old stains. In this test: The dried blood is diluted in a weak acid solution. The antigens are extracted from the stain. Blood grouping is performed using specific antibodies to detect the ABO group. The acid dilution test is highly reliable for blood group determination in forensic cases involving old bloodstains. Incorrect Options: A. Benzidine test: The benzidine test is a presumptive test for the presence of blood. It relies on the peroxidase-like activity of hemoglobin to produce a color change. However, it does not provide any information about the ABO blood group and is not specific to blood group determination. Additionally, it is no longer commonly used due to its carcinogenic nature. C. Haemin crystal test: The haemin crystal test (Teichmann test) is used to confirm the presence of blood in dried stains by detecting hemoglobin. The test involves creating distinctive hemin crystals (by adding a chemical reagent to a blood sample). However, like the benzidine test, it does not identify blood groups. D. Precipitin test: The precipitin test is used to differentiate human blood from animal blood by detecting species-specific proteins (such as albumin). It is not used for blood group identification or typing in dried bloodstains.

questions.text: Which of the following tests is used to detect semen
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Barberio's test • Marsh test is used to detect Arsenic. • Phenolphthalein test is used to detect blood. • Paraffin test is used to detect gun powder residues from the hand. • Barberio’s test, Florence’s test, Acid phosphatase Test, Zinc test, Fluorescence test, Microscopy & Precipitation reaction, ELISA, Prostate specific antigen (P 30) are used to detect semen.

questions.text: For embalming, chemicals are usually injected into
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Carotid artery For embalming, chemicals such as formalin, phenol, and other preservatives are injected into the carotid artery. This is because the carotid artery: Is a large, easily accessible artery. Supplies blood to the head and brain, ensuring effective distribution of embalming fluid to the upper body. Allows for uniform perfusion of the preservative chemicals throughout the body. The carotid artery is often preferred in embalming procedures to ensure effective preservation, particularly of the head and brain, which are critical areas in forensic and mortuary work. Incorrect Options: B. Jugular vein: The jugular vein is not used for injecting embalming fluid. Instead, it is commonly used to drain blood from the body during the embalming process. C. Femoral artery: While the femoral artery can be used for embalming in some cases, it is generally not the primary choice. It is often used for lower-body embalming when access to the carotid artery is not possible. D. Femoral vein: The femoral vein is not used for injecting embalming fluid. Similar to the jugular vein, it is used for blood drainage during embalming.

questions.text: Common salt is used as preservative in case of poisoning by
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Phenol Common salt (sodium chloride) is used as a preservative in cases of phenol poisoning. Phenol is a volatile and degradable compound, and using a saturated salt solution helps to stabilize the phenol in biological specimens (such as stomach contents, vomitus, or tissues). The high salt concentration prevents the breakdown of phenol, ensuring it remains detectable during forensic analysis. This makes common salt a critical preservative for phenol poisoning cases in medico-legal investigations. Incorrect Options: A. Mineral acids: Mineral acids (e.g., hydrochloric acid, sulfuric acid) are stable substances and do not require common salt for preservation. Instead, specimens in such cases are usually refrigerated or preserved with sodium fluoride to prevent putrefaction. Common salt does not play any role in stabilizing mineral acids. B. Alkalis: Alkalis (e.g., caustic soda, potassium hydroxide) are also chemically stable and do not require any specific preservative like common salt. Specimens in alkali poisoning cases are generally preserved by routine refrigeration to avoid degradation of biological material. C. Aconite: Aconite poisoning involves alkaloids, which require preservation with rectified spirit to prevent their degradation. Common salt does not preserve alkaloids and hence is not used in cases of aconite poisoning.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about blood grouping is not correct?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) It is the method to conclusively fix the paternity • Blood grouping helps to solve paternity problems, but does not conclusively fix paternity. • DNA Profiling (Fingerprinting) provides absolute certainty and is a fool proof method to conclusively fix paternity. • Comparing the blood grouping helps to certain extent in case of exchange of babies in maternity hospitals, to match the fragmentary remains of skeleton and to compare the blood stains on the weapons.

questions.text: Match the following
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 1-c; 2-a; 3-d; 4-b • Brain mapping (fMRI) is discovered by Seiji Ogawa. The primary form of fMRI (Functional magnetic resonance imaging) uses the blood-oxygen-level dependent (BOLD) contrast. It is based on uptake of oxygen in the brain cells in response to questionnaire. • Dr. Kary Banks Mullis invented Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR). • Brain fingerprinting is invented by Lawrence Farwell. It is a technique that uses electroencephalography (EEG) to determine whether specific information is stored in a subject's brain by measuring electrical brainwaves and recording a brain response known as a P300-MERMER (memory and encoding related multifaceted electroencephalographic response) in response to words, phrases, or pictures that are presented on a computer screen. • Dr. Alec Jeffrey in 1985 developed DNA fingerprinting.

questions.text: The only test to detect both choline and spermine in seminal stain is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Thin layer chromatography Florence test: • The stain is extracted by 1 % hydrochloric acid and a drop is placed on a glass slide. • A drop of Florence solution (Postassium iodine, iodine and water) is allowed to run under the cover slip. • If semen is present, dark-brown crystals of choline iodide appear immediately. • They are rhombic crystals resembling haemin. • A negative test means the fluid is not semen. Barberio's test: • A saturated aqueous or alcoholic solution of picric acid when added to spermatic fluid, produces yellow needle shaped rhombic crystals of spermine picrate. • In Barberio's test, the presence of spermine in semen is detected. The Acid phosphatase test: • Acid phosphatase activity of human semen per ml is 340 - 360 Bodansky units or 2500 - 3500 Angstorm units. • It is the most commonly used presumptive test for the detection of seminal fluid. • The prostatic secretion element of seminal fluid contains a very much higher percentage of acid phosphatase. Thin layer chromatography detects both choline and spermine in seminal stain.

questions.text: In case of embalming, best method of injection is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Method of injection for Embalming are: • Continuous Injection and drainage: The arterial injection is given continuously, against vein tube that is kept open throughout injection. The embalming time is much shortened. Venous drainage and tissue saturation is poor. This method is least satisfactory. • Continuous injection with disrupted drainage: The injection is made continuously with vein tube closed. The blood in the veins build up a resistance for the arterial flow which helps in the better diffusion of the fluid. Thick blood is discharged when the drain tube is opened. This method is better that continuous discharge and drainage. • Alternate injection and drainage: The arterial fluid is injected for sometimes with the drain tube closed. The injection is stopped when the superficial veins swell, and the drain tube is opened. When the flow of blood from the drain tube stops, it is closed and the injection started. This process is repeated several times till the embalming is complete. • Discontinuous injection and drainage: This consists of repeated arterial injection of small quantities at two hour intervals. The total quantity of injection fluid is in excess of ordinary injection done at a tie. The injection is continued for three ir four times. The venous drain tube which is kept closed is opened a little before and kept open a little after starting another dose of injection. This is the best method. • The main composition of embalming fluid is Formalin, which is a 37% (by weight) or 40% (by volume) aqueous (water) solution of formaldehyde, with the chemical formula HCHO, used as an antiseptic, disinfectant, and especially today as a fixative for histology (the study of tissues under the microscope). The embalming fluid may be injected by Hand/Foot pump, Stirrup pump, Bulb Syringe, Gravity Injector or Motorised Injection (best). • There are different methods of injection namely, Continuous Injection and Drainage Continuous Injection with disrupted Drainage Alternate Injection and Drainage • Discontinuous Injection and Drainage (Best Method) • There are several embalming fluids, but typical embalming fluid is the best.
